thread.title: The Socceroos chasm Brazil threatens to expose
thread.title_full: The Socceroos chasm Brazil threatens to expose

title: The Socceroos chasm Brazil threatens to expose
text:
United fall in ACL opener 1:52 Socceroos attacking options thin ahead of seven crucial games, including a friendly with Brazil February 23, 2017 12:01pm by Kate Cohen with AAP Source: FOX SPORTS BARCELONA, Real Madrid, Paris Saint-Germain, Chelsea and Liverpool. 
Players from these global superpowers could line up for Brazil when they travel down under for a blockbuster friendly against the Socceroos on June 13 at the MCG. 
Brazil are already heading to Melbourne to play Argentina on June 9, with that game billed as Neymar v Messi. 
The enormity of the challenge for Ange Postecoglou? Brazil’s superstars will face players from Bournemouth, Genk, Hangzhou Greentown, Burton Albion and Baniyas. 
The comparison is chalk and cheese, as the current reality for the Socceroos and Australian football means players aren’t able to crack it in big clubs in the biggest leagues. 
Despite the relative success on the international stage, winning the Asian Cup in 2015 and building an identifiable style of play, our best players haven’t made the next step in their club careers. 
Those gaps in the squad now again come to the forefront ahead of three crucial World Cup qualifiers and the friendly against Brazil, which leads immediately into the Confederations Cup. Philippe Coutinho, Neymar and Gabriel Jesus could all be in Australia to face Argentina and the Socceroos. Source: Getty Images 
None more so than in the attacking positions, which provides a stark contrast to Brazil’s riches. 
With Jamie Maclaren’s international career in its infancy, Mathew Leckie enduring a protracted national team goal drought, Adam Taggart on the road back to proving his long-term consistency and Apo Giannou, Robbie Kruse and Nathan Burns all out of season it leaves Ange Postecoglou with limited options in crucial positions. 
While Tomi Juric played 45 minutes for Luzern on the weekend, his fitness concerns saw a potential move to Championship side Reading put on hold. 
Who does that leave? 37-year-old Tim Cahill, a survivor from the 2006 World Cup clash between the countries. 
The all-time Socceroos leading goalscorer, there is no denying Cahill’s never-ending ability to score on the biggest stage – but there are concerns about his durability and ability to withstand the high tempo requirements of Postecoglou’s system. Mathew Leckie is one of a few Socceroos in a top league, but has struggled for goals. Source: Getty Images 
The reality makes for hard reading, but an intriguing test for Postecoglou and his players over the coming months. 
WHO COULD BRAZIL BRING DOWN UNDER? 
Neymar will be the main event should he travel to Australia for the two fixtures. 
With Barcelona all but knocked out of the UEFA Champions League, a potential clash with the final in Cardiff has been avoided. That is one stumbling block out of the way for event organisers – who can also look towards big names such as Philippe Coutinho, Roberto Firmino, Willian, David Luiz and, Champions League commitments permitting, Marcelo and Dani Alves. 
There is also the contingent of big name stars who have moved to the Chinese Super League, including Hulk, Alex Teixeira, Oscar and Ramires. 
After the disaster of falling at the group stage of the Copa America last year, Brazil have now won seven games on the bounce, conceding just once. Hulk delivers stunning winner 0:36 
TICKETS 
Telstra has a pre-sale for customers from 9am on Monday 27 February to 9am Wednesday 1 March, before the window opens for Football Family members from 11am until 11am on Friday 3 March. 
Tickets to the general public open from 12pm on Friday 3 March 2017, but pricing details have not yet been released. 
SOCCEROOS UPCOMING FIXTURES 
— 23 March – Iraq v Australia (WCQ, in Iran) 
— 28 March – Australia v UAE (WCQ, in Sydney) 
— 8 June – Australia v Saudi Arabia (WCQ, in Adelaide) 
— 13 June – Australia v Brazil (Friendly, in Melbourne) 
— 19 June – Australia v Germany (Confederations Cup) 
— 22 June – Cameroon v Australia (Confederations Cup) 
— 25 June – Chile v Australia (Confederations Cup) View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
